And then the kids would get into them, and some of it would get erased.
All the way along, it may be hard for you to follow this story as it was unfolding.
But I just want to say that it would be awfully hard to sit down and just give the history over 18 years, 20 years virtually.
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
And through all that I was gaining experience.
The biggest thing was handling men.
After the first two years that I was in the electrical
business, I was always in charge of men.
And that's the big thing when you're contracting, is you depend on your men doing the work.
You don't do it yourself.
And you have to organize your men and have them working for you and not against you.
And during the years that I worked for the power company, you always - oh - you had difficulties.
Guys would get hard to handle, and
they'd buck you a little bit, and you always - just one thing you had to do, and that's plow them under and keep on moving ahead.
You never look back.
If you had any labor problems, you waded through them and kept on going.
So to get back to when I started out from Midale,
That's where I started building.
I didn't have any equipment.
First thing I did, I went to a dealer in Estevan, and he had a half-ton truck there.
And trucks were hard to come by at that time.
This truck had about 60,000 miles on it.
It was in pretty bad shape.
But I had to have a half-ton truck, and it was the only one available.
So I virtually took it from him.
I said, "I'm going to have that truck, and you can't sell it to anybody else."
I happened to know the dealer very well.
That was the start.
I had a half-ton truck.
Then I rented a man with a truck when I started dismantling airports.
And then I got word that there was some military trucks being sold in Regina.
In fact, the Power Corporation tipped us off to that.
So I come up and I bought an old gun carrier, a great big awkward thing that was built for pulling a gun around the country.
And, what they called, another was a "1500 weight".
It was about a two-ton truck, but equipped for battlefield work.
So I took those trucks and revamped them, took them down to Midale and,
my brother ran a little garage there,
he was able to do welding.
And between the two of us, we got the cutting torches going and got them, made something that would start to function.
There was no steel in the country.
There wasn't -
You couldn't buy anything after the war.
And so I made a wooden derrick -
tripod on the back of this Army truck for setting poles.
We had no digging equipment, just dug the holes by hand.
And I was fortunate enough to get ahold of a couple of experienced diggers.
And they would dig all the holes we needed for a small outfit.
Then a little later, I found out they had another two-ton truck in Regina that the military was selling off.
I got these trucks for virtually nothing.
I got the Army trucks at about $350 a piece, and they were in mint condition.
And then I bought this other truck.
I think I paid $1,100 for it, and it was virtually like a new truck.
So I had pretty good equipment to start with,
just the three trucks, and these army trucks were open.
They didn't have cabs on them.
So you had to put up with that.
In their tough weather, you were sitting out in the open.
Well, then I... Let's see, I worked...
I finished that job dismantling those airports.
That was one hell of a job.
We uncovered...
miles and miles of cable that had been buried about two feet underground.
We were supposed to take it up without damaging it.
Well, I tried every method there was of uncovering that cable, from hand digging right up to getting graders and scraping it down until you got it, but
no way could you go and excavate a half a mile of cable without getting some damage in it; scraping it or digging - even when you're digging by hand you'd rub the shovel into it occasionally. So -
They told us take it out as best we could, and we still had to go through the process of making a trench and pulling the cable out and then filling the trench in again.
I could never figure out how three men,
three different contractors, could sit down and figure out how you dismantled those two airports, overhead lines, underground lines, and everything.
And then use all the usable material to build a power line, as I said, from Halbrite to Midale to Macoun.
And in the three - one - there were four bids!
In the four bids, there was only $1,000 difference from high to low.
I happened to be the low one.
It went all the way from my bid was $10,500 and the highest bid was $11,500.
But it - it was almost unbelievable to think that four men could sit down -
This was something that none of them had ever done before, or none of us had ever done before.
But we come in that close; that's within 10%, which - considered pretty close bidding at any time.
Well, worked in - I finished up in Mydale on that project about the end of November.
Then the Power Commission had some work they wanted done up on the north -
north suburb, what they called North Regina, everything north of the CN tracks.
So I come up and I worked on it through December and January and just had a small crew, I think, four men or so.
And then after that we went to Saskatoon and did a similar job.
This was for wartime housing.
And this was an experience now:
we were digging through frost, anywhere up to four or five foot of frost.
But somehow, well, in Saskatoon it was in sandy ground, you couldn't dig, so I had to put fire, burn the frost out.
And it all worked out pretty good.
You just did what you had to do, and that was it.
Then I came back and I did some work in the town of Davidson for the old Dominion Electric Company.
They were still functioning.
And then I went back to Estevan and just sat in quiet until the spring, when the tenders come out.
Then I got a... the first job was from Weyburn to Radville,
which was a nice job, and it was an early spring.
We were working on that early in April.
And from there on, you just kept on moving ahead.
When I got that job finished, they had a bunch of farms around Weyburn, I did those.
And then I went back to Estevan and started building the
big high voltage line, and that put something else too.
There you got - everything was so heavy and big and we had never dealt with cross arms and insulators and poles.
All the poles were 40 feet or more.
The cross arms were four by sixes, ten feet long.
You had to handle all that heavy stuff.
I still don't know how I was able to make a dollar on the job, but I did.
I finished - worked all summer, besides running out and doing other odd jobs.
That came up from time to time, and I finished that job on the
11th day of December.
We had all the wires drawn, and
it was heavy wire.
That was a new experience, too.
And then I folded up for the winter.

what I did for help - for men.

He could hardly write his own name, but he was a good worker.
Good, honest -

He was just a young fellow out of the Army looking for a job.
He was handy at driving trucks.
He was really good with trucks.
So that gave me the nucleus of a -
of an outfit.

Have five and six men tamping and two men shoveling.

Everything was new.
You had to figure out everything for yourself.
No one had ever
had the experience of doing a job of stringing a line under the cross arms.
Oh, I'll come back to that again.
Everybody wondered, "How can you string wire when the cross arms are on a slant and you can't lay the wire on them?"
Well, I went to Winnipeg.
I figured out if I got some hay pulleys, about four-inch pulleys,
big enough to take a three-quarter inch rope.
I went to Winnipeg, and I went to Ashdown Hardware, and I asked the guy, "Have you got any wooden hay pulleys?
Just the bare pulley I want."
Yeah.
I said, "How many?"
He looked up his inventory.
He had 250.
I said, "I'll take them all."
The guy looked at me like I was out of my tree.
What are you going to do with 250 wooden pulleys?
So I said, "I've got a job for them.
Don't worry.
I'm not buying them just for fun."
However, I - we designed hangers for these pulleys.
They worked out 100%.
Today, they use a pulley to do the same job.
Of course, the conductors are heavier,
but the pulleys they use nowadays cost you probably $100, $150 a piece.
Those cost me about $0.35 a piece.
Well, plus the labor of assembly.
